quoteFirst: After breakfast in the morning, the expedition moved on.
quoteLast: a great avenue was reached, which had in it two endless parallel bars of some kind of hard black substance, raised the height of the tallest Bull Frog above the general level.  The scientists climbed up on these and examined and tested them in various ways.
title: Sketches New and Old
author: Twain, Mark, 1835-1910

quoteFirst: "Son," says Old Hickory, as he pads into the office
quoteLast: next day, "I believe I forgot the usual caddie fee.  There you are."
title: On With Torchy
author: Ford, Sewell, 1868-1946; Lincoln, F. Foster (Frederic Foster) [Illustrator]

quoteLast: , Ringrose and his companions tried to follow the ship, but were driven back upon the shore by a raging sea. Early in the evening they tried a second time, and got some little distance from land, but the waves were so violent that they were forced to throw overboard all their jars of water to lighten their boats.
title: Journeys Through Bookland, Vol. 8
author: Sylvester, Charles Herbert

quoteFirst: and Dodds rode away to the south on a dim trail to find out what move to make; how far we might be able to go down the Dirty Devil the next day. When they got back they reported finding a canyon twelve miles farther on, with many water-pockets, and concluded to go there. We arrived
title: A Canyon Voyage
author: Dellenbaugh, Frederick Samuel, 1853-1935

quoteFirst: The close of the very singular scene exhibited at the _morai_, which I have faithfully described in the last chapter, leaving us no other business in Attahooroo, we embarked
quoteLast: , in order to return to Matavai; and, in our way, visited Towha, who had remained on the little island where we met him the day before. Some conversation passed between Otoo and him, on the present posture of public affairs; and then the latter solicited me once more to join them in their war against Eimeo.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels, Volume 16
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteLast: . A party of friends met us and conducted us about the town, which is a very beautiful one indeed. What I liked best, however, was the hearty welcome that I met with, because it showed, that the reign of calumny and delusion was passed.
title: Rural Rides
author: Cobbett, William, 1763-1835

quoteLast: they renewed their efforts on Mr. Gubbins's side with similar effect. They repeatedly sounded the advance, and were frequently heard abusing each other for not advancing.
title:
The Defence of Lucknow
A Diary Recording the Daily Events during the Siege of the European Residency, from 31st May to 25th September, 1857
author: Wilson, T. F. (Thomas Fourness)

quoteFirst: “Now, my boys, you must never go to the southwest, to the gambling place,” said the father. The next day
quoteLast: the little boy started off alone. He came to a beautiful opening in the woods, at the farther end of which was a lean-to, under which was a man with a very large head (far larger than the head of a buffalo), who played dice for the heads of all who came along.
title:
Seneca Fiction, Legends, and Myths
Thirty-Second Annual Report of the Bureau of American Ethnology; 1910-1911
author: Curtin, Jeremiah, 1835-1906 [Compiler]; Hewitt, J. N. B. (John Napoleon Brinton), 1859-1937 [Compiler]

quoteFirst: We entered the river regularly at eleven and four, but Choti, T'yonni, and I also swam in the lagoon at the mouth of the river, and never suffered bad consequences unless we cut or scraped ourselves on coral.
quoteLast: I prepared my déjeuner à la fourchette, and had a wide choice of shrimp, eels, fish, taro, chicken, breadfruit, yams, and all the other fruits. The solicitude of the homesick missionaries had added to those indigenous, oranges, limes, shaddocks, citrons, tamarinds, guavas, custard apples, peaches, figs, grapes, pineapples, watermelons, pumpkins, cucumbers and cabbages.
title: Mystic Isles of the South Seas.
author: O'Brien, Frederick, 1869-1932

quoteFirst: At daybreak, on the 15th of March, La Perouse made the signal to prepare to sail. On the 17th,
quoteLast: , a light breeze sprung up, with which he got under way. On the 8th of April, about noon, they saw Easter Island.
title:
The American Encyclopedia of History, Biography and Travel
Comprising Ancient and Modern History: the Biography of Eminent Men of Europe and America, and the Lives of Distinguished Travelers.
author: Prescott, Thomas H., 1810-1865
